reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go home now.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The readings are the same as what you learned with the kanji. You know much more than ten percent of this word's reading already.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading for this one is an exception, at least for the 乳 part. It's read as ち, and 首 is read as くび. You can remember the reading of <vocabulary>nipple</vocabulary> by thinking of a very special "nipple" you have on your face. A bee has burrowed into your cheek, and it squirts out milk from its butt, which sticks out of your cheek. You can't get it out, so you've decided to call this little cheek bee nipple your <reading>cheek bee</reading> (ちくび). Buzz buzz *milk*
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use:

What's the <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary> of a <reading>saw</reading> on <reading>yo</reading>gurt (さよう)? What will the <vocabulary>action</vocabulary> of the saw on the yogurt do? Seems futile, but you're going to try anyway. For science.
This word uses the reading of 保守的 for the first half and then the regular kanji readings for the second half. Combine those things and you'll be a master of righteousness and / or kanji.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have <vocabulary>to provide</vocabulary> your friends with their own <reading>sauna</reading> (そな) because they don't want to use your shower. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do people who are <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>kind</vocabulary> say when someone asks of them a favor? Always "<reading>yessir</reading>" (やさ). Always, always "yessir"!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful about しゅつ becoming しゅっ here!

This is the kun'yomi reading for 割 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!
The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you'll use here. It's the わ one, though, making it わる.
This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 加える. To help you distinguish between the two, remember that most verbs ending in わる are intransitive.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You don't fit inside your bed anymore. I guess you've grown? Better get out the trusty <reading>o</reading>ld <reading>saw</reading>s (おさ) and chop off your footboard.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

The only font the machine can print <vocabulary>speech</vocabulary>es in is <reading>serif</reading> font (せりふ).
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
吸血 should be easy for you to read. The 鬼 part uses the reading you already learned with the kanji, き. Easy, no?
The reading is the same as the kanji, so you should be good here. Just imagine yourself  calling out to someone: "<reading>YO</reading> (よ)! You!"
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is the same like 増える. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 委員 as well, since it's 2/3rds of the word.

The reading for this one is a bit difficult, but there's a hint in the kanji. See the 道 in there on the top? What's the reading for the vocab version of that kanji? It's みち. That's the first part. Now, who are you leading? Let's say you're leading a bee back to its nest, via the road. It's a <reading>道 Bee</reading> (みちび)!
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, making it <reading>Kawasaki</reading>.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

When you cut the tree down to produce a <vocabulary>tree trunk</vocabulary>, out jumps <reading>Mickey</reading> Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? <reading>た</reading>てる. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 建築 already.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Imagine yourself trying <vocabulary>to stretch</vocabulary> your favorite toy figurine, seeing just how far you can stretch it. With every stretch, you start laughing uncontrollably, <reading>HA</reading> (は) HA HA HA HA HA. Seems a bit cruel. Are you okay?
The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. See how we divide up the duty of learning kanji into radicals and kanji and vocab? Makes it nice, right? Each piece is its own 役割.
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.
These readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Just keep in mind that 棚 gets rendaku'd to だな.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will be much easier to read this if you know 批判, as well.
The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!
The reading is the same as 挙がる, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

URGH! The reading isn't even the same as 断る, how frustrating. <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> is read as たつ. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater <reading>tots</reading> (たつ). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have <vocabulary>to cut off</vocabulary> tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Read this to be able to remember the meaning, too, which is <vocabulary>Shinkansen</vocabulary>.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

You might sometimes see せこう as an alternative reading, but しこう is the more common version.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It looks like something is going <vocabulary>to appear</vocabulary> in front of you. You are so scared and surprised you can't even speak properly: "<reading>Are wha</reading>t??" (あらわ) you ask, trying to figure out what's appearing in front of you.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading is a combination of the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know 理解 already this one is easy <vocabulary>to comprehend</vocabulary>.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You've already learned both 町 and 外れ, so just combine the two and you get 町外れ not only in meaning, but also in reading!
This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji: かゆ.
The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

"<reading>He-e</reading> (ひい) is going <vocabulary>to excel</vocabulary>," you stutter. "He-e is!"
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji. You haven't learned that yet for 節, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

The real <vocabulary>turning point</vocabulary> in your life was when you got yourself a <reading>few she</reading>ep (ふし). Owning a few sheep was a true <vocabulary>milestone</vocabulary> for you. Now you have all the wool sweaters and cheese you could ever want!
The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, you've learned both of them already. 晴れる is はれる. That's the reading you use here, though は goes to ば.

The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "<reading>村先</reading>" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.

The reading for 紫 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "<reading>村先</reading>" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 羨む, but here's a reminder just in case:

Those <reading>ura</reading>nium <reading>Ya</reading>nkees (うらや) are making you more <vocabulary>envious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>jealous</vocabulary> by the day. They're the new Yankees team that was manufactured in a lab and fed uranium. Their skills are unparalleled because of their metallic strength. Go ahead and feel envious, they'll definitely be #1 this year.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. That's all you have to remember, though, because you've seen both of these readings before!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When you go <vocabulary>to judge</vocabulary> people, there are different types. The one you truly hate the most, however, is the <reading>sobber</reading> (さば). "The Sobber" is the worst kind. They just sob and sob and sob and it's really hard to move on to your next judging.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You hopefully learned this on'yomi for 判 with the word 評判, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:

After your <reading>ban</reading> (ばん) on the WaniKani forums, you now face <vocabulary>trial</vocabulary> before none other than Judge Koichi. He's going to decide whether your ban will be lifted or not. Good luck, there's a lot at stake.
The reading is the same as 解ける, so if you know that you can read this one too.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This uses a slightly different reading from what you learned for 判, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Your <vocabulary>reputation</vocabulary> is incredibly important to you, so don't let anybody know that you've been <reading>ban</reading>ned (ばん) on the WaniKani forums before. Wouldn't want anyone to find out. What, this is going to be published as a reading mnemonic on WaniKani?! What are you talking about? Oh sh-...

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, the reading just comes from 選挙 so if you know that you know this as well.

The 長 is the kun'yomi reading, which comes from 長い. The 崎 part is the same reading that you learned with the kanji (though also kun'yomi). Combine those together and you have <reading>ながさき</reading>. Sound familiar? It should. This is the city of <vocabulary>Nagasaki</vocabulary>, one of the cities in which the A-bombs fell.

The reading is unlike anything you've seen with this kanji. Just think about how you have <vocabulary>to get off</vocabulary> at <reading>O</reading>-station. None of the other letters are your stop. Just <reading>O</reading>-Station (お).

This is a jukugo word, but it actually uses kun'yomi for both 雨 and 戸. Additionally, the reading for 雨 is actually slightly different from what you've learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Have you ever thought a <vocabulary>shutter</vocabulary> is like an <reading>armor</reading> (あま) for a window? They're both protections, and are usually made from metal. Kind of makes sense, right?

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

<vocabulary>Leather</vocabulary> is the skin of a cow, right? How do you say "skin" in Japanese? Remember <reading>皮</reading> (かわ)? It has the same reading as that, and they're both skin, so hopefully that makes it easier to remember.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

<vocabulary>Demon</vocabulary>s are mean. This particular demon bites you on the knee, creating an "O" shape on your knee. He tells you he has cursed you with the <vocabulary>"O" knee</vocabulary> (おに).
